data.title: The “go to definition” link will be abnormal when the id is with "-"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 1607

![8](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8530043/22011760/a48b10e8-dccb-11e6-8809-a65a7c36165b.PNG)

Steps to Reproduce:
1.Create a .ts file, define "vue-router" and input `import * as Router from "vue-router";`.
2.Move the mouse onto the "vue-router" as you press the "Ctrl".

The “go to definition” link will be abnormal, only "vue" or "router" turn blue.

e.g:
I have a dir is `/code/It's good/`
when I copy its path, rather `/code/it's\ good/` than just `/code/it's good/`.

data.title: Add a "complex command" to allow extensions to open a URL in the default web browser
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: All

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Browse https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/vscode-api-commands
2. Don't find a command to open a URL in the default web browser
3. Implement one yourself via the popular, cross-platform [opn](https://www.npmjs.com/package/opn) package
4. Get [bug report for Linux](https://github.com/DavidAnson/vscode-markdownlint/issues/4) because `vsce` doesn't preserve the `execute` bit of `xdg-open`

VS Code already implements this functionality; this issue just asks to expose it.

Note: A fix for this issue would allow you to close https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-vsce/issues/152

data.title: Intellisense is not working inside the nested-intilializer block
Add a setting for case sensitive sorting in explorer
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: Version 1.8.1 (1.8.1)
- OS Version: OSX 10.12.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code
2. Open project folder
3. Open file explorer
4. Review File Tree

Looks like it's caused by this in ```vscode/src/vs/base/common/comparers.ts (line 10)```:
```
const FileNameComparer = new Intl.Collator(undefined, { numeric: true, sensitivity: 'base' });
```

could be changed to:
```
const FileNameComparer = new Intl.Collator(undefined, { numeric: true, sensitivity: 'case' });
```
or
```
const FileNameComparer = new Intl.Collator(undefined, { numeric: true, sensitivity: 'variant' });
```

Ideally this would be controlled in the user/workspace settings...

In the mean time, is there a way to manually change this in my local running copy?  Thnxs!

data.title: Please allow multiple commands per keybinding
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: Version 1.9.0-insider
- OS Version: Linux Mint 18.1 Cinnamon 64 bit

Steps to Reproduce:
Feature request...
1. open Keyboard Shortcuts from File Prefs menu. keybindings.json
2. look at the triple of: key, command, when.
3. please allow command to also have type Array of String, not just String. 
4. The point is to allow user to run several commands one after the other with one shortcut.
Example: build code, focus on errors pane, 
``` 
        {
	"key": "F8",
	"command":  [ "workbench.action.tasks.build" , 
                      "workbench.action.showErrorsWarnings" ]
	},
```

data.title: Strange behaviours of formatting in Visual Studio Code
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1 - OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.2 The shortcut `shift+alt+f` is used to format the whole document (without having to select anything), and `cmd+k cmd+f` is used to format the selection. ``` { "key": "shift+alt+f", "command": "editor.action.formatDocument", "when": "editorHasDocumentFormattingProvider && editorTextFocus && !editorReadonly" }, { "key": "cmd+k cmd+f", "command": "editor.action.formatSelection", "when": "editorHasDocumentFormattingProvider && editorHasSelection && editorTextFocus && !editorReadonly" }, ``` My experiments show that formatting html does not work well in some cases. For instance, 1) ``` {{post.title}}
posted by
 ``` will be formatted to ``` {{post.title}}
posted by
 ``` 2) ```
abc
``` will be formatted to ```
abc
``` Does anyone know what's happening here? Are they bugs?

data.title: feature request: multiple named keybinding contributions to work with global keymap

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Allow an extension to supply multiple, *named*, keybinding contributions to correspond with the active keymap. E.g. if an extension contributes keybindings for "vim" (or "emacs"), then they should be enabled when the user selects a vim (resp. emacs) keymap. And also allow the user to manually specify the name of a keybinding contribution to activate, or `none`, per extension in settings.json. Keymap name `"vscode"` should be reserved for vscode's default keybindings, and an extension may optionally provide a default keybinding contribution to activate for all other keymaps.

This feature request is a finer-grained extension of #18441. 

Concrete example: my vscoq extension provides language support for Coq, and incoming users are used to very different keybindings depending on whether they're coming from CoqIDE, vim, or emacs. Ideally, I would be able to provide the default keybindings for all of them (in addition to the default bindings that I have chosen to work well with vscode's defaults) -- and the right one would automatically be selected when the user changes their keymap.

At the moment, I can provide additional keymap extensions that a user can manually select from. But it's not nice that a user has to first choose to use an emacs keymap extension, and then manually configure all of their extensions to also provide emacs-like keybindings (by downloading additional keymap extensions or tediously creating their own keybindings).

data.title: Ligatures related with `*` does not work
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64 RS2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install a font with ligature support, like Iosevka and Fira Code
2. Enable Ligatures
3. Type `<*` or `<*>`

Expected Result:
Ligatures work. For Fira Code, the `*` is enlarged. For Iosevka, it is centered.

Actual Result:
Ligatures do not works.

Additional Information:
May related with electron/electron#8405.
The same ligature in Chrome itself works.

data.title: Javascript syntax highlighting broken with RequireJS style files
Overwriting / munging/ corrupting files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.2.2

Steps to Reproduce:
Sorry I don't really know how to reproduce it - it happens randomly.  But here is what happens:

I'm working on a.js and b.js.  I'll go to debug  (an electron app) and it will fail. Then I'll check out the failure place and somehow a whole chunk of a.js will have inserted into b.js.  I wind up either having to find the chunk and remove it or revert to my last saved state.

It's basically unworkable and I've had to switch back to Sublime. But clearly VSCode is used by tons of people, so this can't be a common occurrence.  

Any ideas of how to even debug what's going on or reproduce it?

data.title: Test: dirty files are preserved when renaming or moving around
data.body:
Refs: #11997

- [x] @mousetraps 
- [x] @kieferrm 

You can now move or rename dirty files without having to save them first. Verify for all of the following actions that the dirty contents and dirty state are preserved and restored:
* rename file
* rename parent of file
* move file
* move parent of file

data.title: Test: new setting if files and folders should open in last active or new instance
data.body:
Refs: #371

- [x] win @dbaeumer 
- [x] mac @egamma 
- [x] linux @roblourens 

New settings `window.openFilesInNewWindow` and `window.openFoldersInNewWindow` are provided to control if files and folders should open in the last active instance or new instance. 
Verify:
* the description of the settings make sense in preferences
* changing the values of either makes it behave as expected when opening files and folders

data.title: Test: new setting to control menu visibility
data.body:
- [x] win @joaomoreno
- [x] win @alexandrudima 

A new setting `window.menuBarVisibility` was added to control the visibility of the top level menu. 
* verify that changes to this setting update live without restart
* verify the menu is always visible, even in fullscreen mode when you set `visible`
* verify the menu is always hidden, even when pressing the Alt key when you set `hidden`
* verify the menu is hidden but can be shown pressing the Alt key when you set `toggle`
* verify you can still show/hide the menu from the View menu
